item.title: Number of moves to solve the Tower of Hanoi and its 2 variants
item.description:
If we denote $a_n$ as the optimal number of moves to solve the puzzle with $n$ pegs,

The recurrence relation for the classical variant is

$a_n=2a_{n-1}+1.$

The recurrence relation for the adjacent pegs variant is

$a_n=3a_{n-1}+2.$

For the cyclic variant, we additionally define $b_n$ as the number of moves required to move $n$ pegs to its next clockwise peg.

$a_n$ is not $2b_n$. You can verify with the case $n=2$, obtaining $a_2=7$ and $b_2=5.$ (try it!)
The recurrence relation for the cyclic variant is

$$a_n=2a_{n-1}+b_{n-1}+2, b_n=2a_{n-1}+1.$$

$$ \Rightarrow a_n=2a_{n-1}+(2a_{n-2}+1)+2$$

Try thinking about the recurrence relation of these variants when there are more than $3$ rods-

For a detailed explanation and illustrations, please refer to the article.
